document_data.name: Red Ache
document_data.mainbody: '''Red ache''' was a [[disease]] that caused the skin to become inflamed and the body to become weakened.
document_data.Acquisition:
The disease could be acquired after sustaining an injury from an infected creature{{Cite web enhancement/Deity Do's and Don'ts|7}} It could potentially also be contracted from injuries received from rusty metal.{{Cite web| url = http://www.wizards.com/default.asp?x=dnd/oa/20011221a| title = House of Harpies| work = | date = 2001| author = [[Owen K.C. Stephens]] | publisher = [[Wizards of the Coast]]| accessdate = | archiveurl     = https://web.archive.org/web/20090123093048/http://wizards.com/dnd/article1.asp?x=dnd/oa/oa20011221a,3 | archivedate    = 2009-01-22 }}

Known carriers included [[jungle landwyrm]]s, [[plague ant]]s, [[undead]] flies, and [[giant leech]]es.{{Cite dungeon| issue  = 86| title  = Rana Mor: Quest for the Rain Tiger| author = [[Richard Baker]]| editor = [[Kim Mohan]]| date   = June 1984| url    = | pages  = 50}} It could also be inflicted via the ''[[contagion]]'', ''[[contagious touch]]'', ''[[epidemic (spell)|epidemic]]'', and ''[[plague cloud]]'' spells.{{Cite dragon/309/Arcane Lore: War Spells|50}}
document_data.Effects: Red ache was a corruption of the blood{{Cite dragon| issue  = 338| title  = Imps of Ill-Humor: Imbalance Incarnate| author = [[David Schwartz]]| editor = [[Erik Mona]]| date   = December 2005| url    = | pages = 32}} that caused the infected's skin to become swollen, red, and hot. It subsequently led to a steady loss of physical strength, possibly leading to death if not treated. Even post-mortem, the effects of red ache prevented the skin from decaying properly, with it remaining red, warm, and swollen. A deceased could still appear alive on casual inspection, even if infested with maggots within.<ref>
document_data.Curing:
Red ache was treatable and ultimately curable, either on one's own or especially with the help of a talented healer. 

Prolonged exposure to the red ache could eventually allow an individual to develop an immunity to it.
